translation.en: [woman] I wanna call it a nightmare.
[woman 2] It was
absolutely wrong from the beginning.
[woman 3] I personally think it was an experiment for him,
translation.ko: 개인적으로 그 사람은 이걸 실험으로 생각했다고 봐요

translation.en: some sick game.
[woman 4] I think about the "why" every single day.
translation.ko: 그런 짓을 '왜' 했을지 매일 생각해요 "내가 너를 모태에 짓기 전에 너를 알았다"

translation.en: Hi, Jacoba, this is Dr. Webber calling.
I have your lab results in.
So give me a call when you have a chance, and we can go over those.
translation.ko: 시간 날 때 전화 주세요 같이 검토해 봐요

translation.en: -Thank you. Bye. -[faucet running]
Hi, this message is for Jacoba Ballard. This is Jane over at Dr. Chan's office.
translation.ko: 안녕하세요, 저코바 밸러드 챈 박사님 사무실의 제인이에요

translation.en: Give us a callback. We want to reschedule you for an appointment. Thanks so much.
translation.ko: 진료 예약 변경 때문에 연락했어요 전화 부탁해요, 고마워요

translation.en: [Jacoba] Growing up, I felt different.
I'm this blonde-haired, blue-eyed person
in a family with dark hair
translation.ko: 가족은 검은 머리에 올리브색 피부와 검은 눈을 지녔죠

translation.en: and, like, olive skin and dark eyes.
So, I kept asking my mom
if I was adopted.
I kept, like, reassuring my parents,
and I'm like, "It's fine if I am, you can tell me. It'll be okay."
translation.ko: 입양된 거라도 괜찮으니까 그냥 얘기해 달라고 했어요

translation.en: Finally, my mom told me the truth.
So, I've known since the age of ten
that I was from donor sperm.
translation.ko: 정자를 기증받아 태어났다는 걸 알고 자랐죠

translation.en: [woman sighing] I believe it was 1979,
and… I wanted a child so bad,
but my husband could not have children.
So I went to see Dr. Cline
for artificial insemination.
I was young.
I think, like, 20, 21.
He was professional.
[Debbie] Uh, we didn't really say a lot.
I mean, he just told us that he would match us with a donor
translation.ko: 제 남편을 닮은 기증자를 찾아 그 사람의 정자를 사용하겠다고 했죠

translation.en: that looked like my husband.
He was gonna use medical students,
their sperm.
And so, when I start ovulating,
I went in, they did the procedure…
and, um, I went home, and I was pregnant.
translation.ko: 그런 뒤 집으로 돌아갔고 그렇게 임신했어요

translation.en: [Debbie] She's my everything.
[smacking lips] I love that child more than life itself.
[Jacoba] I always had this longing for siblings.
I just wanted somebody that related to me,
that's, you know, my brother or sister,
and I just wanted to have that bond.
When I was around the age of 18,
you know, around, like, 1999,
there wasn't commercial DNA testing.
All I knew was my mom went to Dr. Donald Cline,
translation.ko: 제가 아는 거라곤 엄마가 도널드 클라인 박사에게 갔었고

translation.en: and he was the go-to doctor.
translation.ko: 그 사람이 불임 분야에서 유명했다는 사실이었어요

translation.en: My mom was told that
they used a medical resident for donor sperm,
and they never used the medical resident or the donor,
say, more than three times.
translation.ko: 세 번 초과 사용하는 일은 없다고 했대요

translation.en: So, since there was me,
I figured that I might have one or two half-siblings.
translation.ko: 일단 그중 하나가 저니까 이복 형제자매가 한두 명은 있겠다고 생각했어요

translation.en: So, I looked him up, and I called him at his office.
translation.ko: "생육하고 번성하라" 그래서 연락처를 찾아 사무실로 전화를 걸었는데

translation.en: He actually answered the phone.
I wanted to know if he had a donor number
or my mom's medical records
to where I could have some kind of identifying information.
translation.ko: 기증자 신원을 확인할 만한 정보가 있는지 궁금했는데

translation.en: He was very
straightforward, matter-of-fact,
um, no empathy.
But I remember asking him,
like, telling him I wanted to find half-siblings,
and he said that I can't ever know that information.
translation.ko: 그랬더니 그 정보는 절대 알 수 없다고 했어요

translation.en: My mother's records have been destroyed.
[Jacoba] He wished me good luck, and that was it.
I just went on with life and, you know,
translation.ko: 그 후로는 그냥 제 삶을 살았고

translation.en: married, raised my children, and hoped that someday maybe
translation.ko: 결혼해서 아이들을 키우며 언젠가는 형제자매 한둘을

translation.en: I would find a sibling or two.
Watching our friends' children growing up around us
left us feeling isolated and desperate.
But as we found out, we were not alone.
translation.ko: 하지만 알고 보니 우리만 그런 게 아니더군요

translation.en: One out of five couples living in the United States
translation.ko: 미국에서 사는 다섯 쌍 중 한 쌍은

translation.en: experience infertility problems.
[promo narrator] The physicians and staff at Indianapolis Infertility
can help you understand your particular infertility problem more clearly.
translation.ko: 여러분의 불임 문제를 더욱 명확히 이해하도록 도울 것입니다

translation.en: Both Dr. Donald Cline and Dr. Robert Colver
translation.ko: 도널드 클라인 박사와 로버트 콜버 박사는

translation.en: are specialists in the field of infertility
and have achieved excellent results
in diagnosing and treating thousands of infertile couples.
[woman] Dr. Cline was the best-known infertility doctor in Indianapolis.
translation.ko: 클라인 박사는 인디애나폴리스에서 가장 유명한 불임 전문의였어요

translation.en: And I started working for him
translation.ko: 제가 그 사람과 일한 게 "잰 쇼어 클라인의 전 공인 간호사"

translation.en: I worked 13 years.
[man] I was partnered with Dr. Cline from 1987 to 1991, and I have to say,
my career wouldn't be what it has been over the last 35 years
translation.ko: 그 사람 덕분에 "닥터 로버트 콜버 클라인의 전 동업자"

translation.en: if it hadn't been for Don Cline. So…
translation.ko: 지난 35년 동안 제 경력을 꽃피울 수 있었어요

translation.en: You know, I have a very special place in my heart for that man.
translation.ko: 그래서 마음속으로 아주 각별히 여기고 있죠

translation.en: Before '85, for an insemination
or for a donor insemination,
fresh sperm was used.
And back then, you didn't have, like today,
you go on a website, 300 guys show up.
[Jan] We had a notebook
so they could pick from what donor criteria they wanted.
translation.ko: 그걸 보고 원하는 기준에 맞춰 기증자를 골랐죠

translation.en: The hospital was-- It's just right across the street.
translation.ko: 큰 병원이 바로 길 건너편에 있어서

translation.en: And I actually went to the hospital and met some of the donors
translation.ko: 제가 직접 가서 기증자 몇 명을 만났어요

translation.en: because they were residents, and I knew 'em.
And they would pass me the specimen, and I would take it back to the office.
It has to be kept warm, body temperature.
And so I transported the sample in my bra,
so the sperm was still viable by the time I got it over at the office.
translation.ko: 사무실에 도착할 때까지 정자가 살아 있어야 하니까요

translation.en: It was a great field. It was really interesting.
We were putting tubes back together so people… women could get pregnant.
translation.ko: 여자들이 임신할 수 있도록 나팔관을 다시 이어 붙였는데

translation.en: And he had a terrific success rate at that.
[Robert] We'd do laser surgery on tubes,
and that was a new thing that Don did that other doctors didn't do.
translation.ko: 다른 의사들은 하지 않던 돈만의 수술법이었어요

translation.en: For these couples, you have to have them
really think through this, talk through this, pray about it.
translation.ko: 진지하게 고민하고 잘되길 기도할 시간이 필요해요 "아기를 만들다"

translation.en: Really feel like you thought through this whole thing, because
once you do that donor insemination
and they get pregnant, that's their baby. Forever.
translation.ko: 임신하게 되면 영원히 부부의 아기가 되거든요

translation.en: [woman] It was always very emotional
translation.ko: 여자 친구 중 한 명이 연락해서

translation.en: when one of your girlfriends would call you and say she was pregnant
translation.ko: 여자 친구 중 한 명이 연락해서 임신 소식을 전하면 감정이 많이 격해졌죠

translation.en: because there were several times that I'd get off the phone,
translation.ko: "다이애나 키슬러 클라인의 환자" 전화를 끊고 운 적도 몇 번이나 있었어요

translation.en: and I'd just cry because I wanted a child so bad.
translation.ko: 전화를 끊고 운 적도 몇 번이나 있었어요 아이를 간절히 원했거든요

translation.en: My husband and I had gone to various fertility doctors
trying to find… my issue.
It was hard on me and my husband.
But I thought, "Okay. I've finally found a doctor that might be able to help us
translation.ko: 그러다가 드디어 우리 문제를 해결해 줄 의사를 찾았다고 생각했어요

translation.en: because he was so well-known."
I was about 27.
I, uh… My husband and I talked about having our own children.
translation.ko: "리즈 화이트 클라인의 환자" 남편과 아이를 갖는 얘기를 했는데

translation.en: My husband got tested, and he was infertile.
I was told, "The only person who's doing live sperm donor insemination
translation.ko: 살아 있는 정자로 수정시켜 주는 의사는

translation.en: is Dr. Don Cline."
"He's the best of the best, so go to him."
translation.ko: 최고 중의 최고니까 그 사람과 상담하라고 했어요

translation.en: [Liz] By that point, it'd been two and a half years
of having my period when I wanted to really conceive,
taking my temperature, and… for every month and every day.
So it was the first time I felt-- It was hopeful.
[Dianna] I carried my husband's sperm in a little container.
translation.ko: 남편의 정액을 작은 용기에 담아서 가져갔어요

translation.en: Well, we didn't have much time because you had to have it there,
translation.ko: 시간이 많지 않았어요 1시간 이내로 가져가야 했거든요

translation.en: I think, within an hour.
And then there was this room
that I would go into for the artificial insemination, right then with the sperm,
with some kind of long, like, um…
Well, it looked like a needle-type thing, but that was all I remember.
translation.ko: 주삿바늘 같은 걸 사용했어요 기억하는 건 그것뿐이에요

translation.en: [Liz] He'd walk me back to the exam room,
I'm lying down, and my knees are up in the air.
He said, "Okay. I'm gonna, uh, put this… this specimen in you."
translation.ko: 클라인 박사가 이렇게 말했죠 '이 샘플을 몸에 넣겠습니다'

translation.en: So I wait on the table for about 20 minutes.
I was thinking actually positive thoughts.
I was thinking,
"Wow. I might be able to have a child."
When the doctor's office called me
and told me I was pregnant,
I… I couldn't believe it.
[Dianna] We were just so happy when I had her.
I even took Julie back into the office and then showed her off to Dr. Cline.
translation.ko: 줄리를 사무실로 데려가서 클라인 박사에게 보여 주기도 했죠

translation.en: I thought I had altitude sickness.
So I laid off a little bit of skiing,
and ate more crackers, and drank some tea,
translation.ko: 크래커를 더 먹고 차도 더 많이 마셨어요

translation.en: and, um, never thinking I was pregnant.
I thought I was just late.
I was ecstatic.
I thought it was a gift at the time.
[Jacoba] In 2014, you see 23andMe
on, like, every other commercial on TV.
I was 35,
and I told my husband I was gonna take a DNA test
because I figured, at least, I had one or two siblings.
I felt like it was kind of a bonus if I did find the donor,
translation.ko: 기증자까지 찾으면 더 좋겠다고 생각은 했지만

translation.en: but that wasn't, like, my goal. My goal was to find a sibling.
translation.ko: 그래도 제 목표는 형제자매를 찾는 거였어요

translation.en: [Jacoba] The fall of 2014,
I received my results.
I remember that day vividly.
It came back that I was related to
seven siblings.
It was actually immediate excitement, um,
with concern.
Finding out that I had siblings was amazing,
but there's, you know, eight of us. What… what's going on here?
translation.ko: 저를 포함해서 여덟 명이라니 대체 무슨 일인가 했죠

translation.en: Because my mom was told
that they never used a donor more than three times.
translation.ko: 기증된 정자를 세 번 초과 사용하지 않았다고 했거든요

translation.en: Three times was the ideal.
We didn't want a large population
with all the same father.
There's the concern for consanguinity,
uh, having too many people in a certain geographic area
that could potentially be your brother or your sister, and you didn't know it.
translation.ko: 특정 지역에 너무 많으면 안 되는 거죠

translation.en: Because you could potentially have a brother and sister marrying.
translation.ko: 남매가 결혼하게 될 가능성이 생기는 거잖아요

translation.en: This doesn't make sense.
Obviously, you used someone's sperm more than three times.
[Jacoba] And that's when we started to do our own investigating.
Every weekend, we would call each other,
or we would plug names into Ancestry and work on a family tree.
translation.ko: 앤세스트리에 이름을 등록해서 가계도를 그려 넣었죠

translation.en: We joked one day, trying to figure it out,
and we're like, "Wouldn't it be crazy if it was the doctor?"
But we disregarded it, and we're like,
"Probably not, but we'll go through this journey together."
"We'll help each other find who our biological father is."
We were able to just focus on our paternal matches,
and we all matched a lady named Sylvia,
who was our second cousin,
and she was on 23andMe.
So, we had messaged her.
I asked her what surnames was in her family tree,
translation.ko: 실비아의 가계도에 어떤 성이 있는지 물었죠

translation.en: and she gave us a whole list of names.
One of the names that popped up was Swinford.
Swinford is Donald Cline's mother's maiden name.
translation.ko: 스윈퍼드는 도널드 클라인 모친의 결혼 전 성이에요

translation.en: I said, "By any chance,
do you have the name Cline in your family?"
translation.ko: 가족 중에 있는지 물었더니 답변이 왔죠

translation.en: She said, "Oh yes, I completely forgot. My cousin Don."
translation.ko: '네, 까맣게 잊고 있었어요 내 사촌 돈이 있거든요'

translation.en: "He's a doctor."
[Jacoba] Right then, my stomach dropped,
and I felt sick because she just confirmed
translation.ko: 구역질이 날 것 같았죠 이미 알고 있었지만

translation.en: what I think we probably already knew, but we were hoping wasn't true.
translation.ko: 사실이 아니길 바랐던 일이 사실로 확인됐으니까요

translation.en: Dr. Donald Cline
could be our biological father.
I was in shock.
There were so many emotions.
So many questions.
He lied about a donor being used.
Why did he do it?
And how long did he do it?
And how many siblings do we have?
I honestly didn't know who to go to.
I googled, like, "Where do you make a complaint against a doctor?"
That, in turn, led to me filing a complaint
with the Attorney General's office for Indiana.
So, then I received a form back from the Attorney General's office
that was like, their generic messaging like,
"Hi. We've received your complaint, and it's gonna be investigated further,
translation.ko: '안녕하세요 귀하의 불만이 접수되었으며' '조사를 진행한 뒤 연락 드리겠습니다'

translation.en: and someone will be in touch."
We waited and waited. Nobody was returning my calls.
translation.ko: 우린 계속 기다렸지만 검찰청에 전화해도 소용없고

translation.en: No questioning, nothing from the Attorney General's office.
[Jacoba] I wanted answers.
So I reached out to every news outlet, big and small,
translation.ko: 그래서 크고 작은 언론사를 찾아 죄다 연락을 돌렸는데

translation.en: and nobody would pick up the story.
…and I'm Angela Ganote.
Yeah. We're starting off on a chilly start today,
but it's gonna warm up and warm up fast.
[Jacoba] I was watching TV one day,
and I was like… [exhaling sharply] …"Her!"
-[phones ringing] -[Jacoba] "I forgot to send it to her."
[Angela] In February of 2015, I logged onto Facebook,
and I had a message from Jacoba.
The message was in-depth,
saying that she believed a doctor in Indianapolis
had inseminated multiple women with his own sperm.
translation.ko: 자신의 정액을 여러 명의 여성에게 주입했다면서요

translation.en: It was shocking, but it was also backed by proof.
translation.ko: 충격적이기만 한 게 아니라 "앤절라 가노트 폭스59 기자" 증거까지 있었어요

translation.en: Before Jacoba came to me,
she had reached out to Attorney General of our state,
the Attorney General of the United States.
She had reached out to national news organizations,
and she had gotten no response.
And I thought, "Why is no one listening, or at least
translation.ko: 왜 아무도 귀담아듣지 않았을까요? 적어도 진실을 찾으려고는 해 봐야 하지 않나 싶었어요

translation.en: finding the truth?"
translation.ko: 적어도 진실을 찾으려고는 해 봐야 하지 않나 싶었어요

translation.en: I walked into our news director's office,
and I said, "You guys are not gonna believe this."
translation.ko: 도저히 못 믿을 일이 하나 있다고 얘기했죠

translation.en: [Angela] I reached out to Dr. Cline in the very beginning.
He told me that he was not the father.
He told me that he only used sperm from a doctor in training,
that there is no way possible
that the siblings had more than three brothers or sisters.
translation.ko: 형제자매가 셋 초과 나올 가능성은 절대 없다고 했죠

translation.en: I asked if he would like to see the DNA evidence.
translation.ko: 저는 DNA 증거를 보고 싶냐고 묻고

translation.en: I asked him if he would like to provide his own DNA
translation.ko: 이들을 돕기 위해 본인의 DNA를 제공할

translation.en: so that he could help them.
"If you're not the father, have a DNA test and prove to them."
And he wouldn't.
[Angela] So when we first aired the first story,
translation.ko: 첫 번째 취재 내용을 방송했을 때

translation.en: I couldn't use his name, and that was, um, hard for me.
translation.ko: 본명을 사용할 수가 없어서 참 힘들었어요

translation.en: Sisters, born here in Indiana, uncover a family secret.
translation.ko: 인디애나에서 태어난 남매들이 가족의 비밀을 밝힙니다

translation.en: Their dad is not their biological father.
They are donor children,
the product of an anonymous man who donated his sperm.
translation.ko: 이들의 친부는 정자를 기증한 익명의 남자입니다

translation.en: [Jacoba] Since we didn't have Donald Cline's DNA,
we couldn't really move forward
until we had him take a DNA test
to prove that he was our biological father.
translation.ko: 우리의 친부라는 것을 증명할 수 있었죠

translation.en: Like, we knew it in our gut, but we didn't have anybody at the state
that would get back with us, and
they weren't in any hurry to get a DNA sample from him.
translation.ko: 서둘러 DNA 샘플을 확보할 생각도 없는 것 같았어요 "조사가 진행될 예정입니다"

translation.en: [Jacoba] So, one of my half-siblings
messaged all of Cline's children and grandchildren
that were over the age of 18.
Basically said,
"Our mothers went through infertility treatment."
"Did somebody in your family donate sperm?"
translation.ko: '혹시 가족 중에 정자를 기증한 사람이 있나요?'

translation.en: [Jacoba] It was probably a week or two later,
Cline's son messaged me.
So, I met with Doug and Donna,
translation.ko: 그래서 클라인의 두 자녀인 더그와 도나

translation.en: which are two of Cline's children, with his wife, Audrey.
I chose to do it at my church
because I felt more comfortable.
I don't know these people,
and these are some big accusations.
They said they had talked to their dad,
and he did admit that he was our biological father.
translation.ko: 자신이 우리 친부라는 걸 인정했다고 했어요

translation.en: But Doug said that the only time that Cline used his sperm
translation.ko: 하지만 더그는 클라인이 자신의 정자를 사용한 건

translation.en: was when he didn't have access to a donor,
and as far as siblings go,
there was absolutely no more than ten.
[woman] I had seen the news pop on one night…

"And I feel like it's time that the prosecutor, or the Attorney General,

Jacoba and a lot of the individuals touched by this were very emotional,
